Package com.seagullsw.appinterface.client.java

This package provides support for Java command beans, in the form of the command bean abstract superclass AppInterfaceCommand and its associated exception classes.

See: Description

  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    AppInterfaceCommand
    The abstract class AppInterfaceCommand is the system-supplied base "application command bean" (or "host function access bean") class.
  • Exception Summary 
    Exception Description
    AppInterfaceCommandException
    The supertype of checked exceptions thrown when a runtime problem is encountered by an AppInterfaceCommand command bean.
    AppInterfaceCommandFailureResponseException
    Checked exceptions of type AppInterfaceCommandFailureResponseException are thrown by an AppInterfaceCommand command bean when its executing interface function returns normally, but with some failure code set in the response.
    AppInterfaceCommandIllegalStateException
    Unchecked exceptions of type AppInterfaceCommandIllegalStateException are thrown when a runtime problem is encountered by an AppInterfaceCommand command bean because it is not in an appropriate state ("new", "initialized", or "executed") for an attempted operation, such as a message to execute, or to extract arguments or results.
    AppInterfaceCommandInvocationException
    Checked exceptions of type AppInterfaceCommandInvocationException are thrown by an AppInterfaceCommand command bean to signal function invocation or processing errors that prevented its interface function from completing an execution request.
    AppInterfaceCommandRuntimeException
    The class AppInterfaceCommandRuntimeException is the supertype of unchecked exceptions thrown when a runtime problem is encountered by an AppInterfaceCommand command bean.
    AppInterfaceCommandUnknownDataElementException
    Unchecked exceptions of type AppInterfaceCommandUnknownDataElementException are thrown when a runtime problem is encountered by an AppInterfaceCommand command bean because of an attempt to access an undefined data element (argument or result) for its interface function.

Package com.seagullsw.appinterface.client.java Description

This package provides support for Java command beans, in the form of the command bean abstract superclass AppInterfaceCommand and its associated exception classes.

Introduction

A command bean is (an instance of) a subclass of AppInterfaceCommand that enables your Java client program to invoke a particular application interface function.  Command beans are generated by the Interface Definition Tool, if that option is selected when you publish your interface function definitions.  Because the command bean (together with some related runtime classes) takes care of all XML encoding/decoding and all the details of the communications protocol with the Application Interface Server, it provides an easy way for you to access your host application via Java.

A command bean has methods for setting the argument values (inputs), invoking the function, and retrieving the result values (outputs). The methods for setting the argument values and retrieving the result values are specific to the function. For example, if you have a function that retrieves a customer's last name given the customer's ID number, the generated command bean would contain methods such as setArg_customerID(int id) and getResult_customerLastName() (The actual method names depend on the names you supply when creating the interface function definition.) The command bean is sent the AppInterfaceCommand.execute() message to invoke the interface function.

 

Simple Example: A Command Bean and its Client


We present a brief example to summarize the key features of a command bean and to illustrate how to write a Java client program to invoke the functionality encapsulated by the bean.

 

The XML interface function definition

 

Consider a simple "GetCustomer" function that takes a customer ID as input and returns a structure with fields for the last name, first name, and so on. The XML for the interface function definition might look like this:

 

<Function name="GetCustomer">
     <ArgumentTypes>
          <Field name="id" type="integer"/>
     </ArgumentTypes>
     <ResultType>
         <Structure name="Customer">
              <Description>
                   A hand-built Customer schema used as a test fixture.
              </Description>
              <Field name="id" type="integer"/>
              <Field name="lastName" type="string"/>
              <Field name="firstName" type="string"/>
              <Field name="phoneNumber" type="string"/>
              <Field name="emailAddress" type="string"/>
         </Structure>
     </ResultType>
</Function>

 

The command bean


The important aspects of the generated command bean for this interface function are as follows:

 
public class GetCustomerCommand extends AppInterfaceCommand {

 
     /**
      * This constructor configures the new command bean to
      * communicate with an Application Interface Server (AIS)
      * via a default AppInterfaceConnection, instantiated
      * automatically by the static factory method
      * AppInterfaceConnectionFactory.createDefaultConnection().
      *
      * The default connection is the client of a socket at IP address
      * "localhost" and port defined by the int constant
      * com.seagullsw.appinterface.comm.AppInterfaceCommunicationConstants.DEFAULT_SOCKET_PORT
      * (e.g. 1208).
      *
      * Alternatively, the command bean can be configured with a
      * different connection, for remote AIS communication via a desired
      * socket (at a specified IP address and port number) or using HTTP,
      * by passing that connection to the one-argument command bean
      * constructor provided below.
      */
     public GetCustomerCommand() {
          super();
     }

 
     /**
      * This constructor configures the new command bean to communicate with
      * an Application Interface Server (AIS) via an AppInterfaceConnection
      * --- using either a socket at a particular IP address and port number,
      * or HTTP --- that the client has instantiated by means of static
      * factory method calls such as the following:
      *
      * AppInterfaceConnectionFactory.createSocketConnection(
      *      String ipAddress, int portNumber)
      *
      * AppInterfaceConnectionFactory.createHTTPConnection(
      *      String ipAddress)
      *
      * @see AppInterfaceConnectionFactory
      */
     public GetCustomerCommand( AppInterfaceConnection connection ) {
          super( connection );
     }

     /**
      * The command bean's <code>init()</code> method sets the interface
      * function name and then calls the super method, in that order.
      *
      * After <code>init()</code>, the bean will answer true to
      * <code>isNew()</code> and false to <code>isInitialized()</code>
      * if any required function arguments need to be set; once all
      * required arguments have been set, it will answer false to
      * <code>isNew()</code> and true to <code>isInitialized()</code>.
      *
      * This method may be called by clients to restore the bean to its
      * originally constructed state, in particular clearing the function
      * arguments by initializing a new request object for the bean.
      */
     public void init() {
          setFunctionName( "GetCustomer" );
          super.init();
     }

     /**
      * Sets the command bean's argument value for the <code>id</code>
      * property.
      */
     public void setArg_id( int value ) { ... }
 
     /**
      * Returns the command bean's argument value for the <code>id</code>
      * property.
      *
      * @exception AppInterfaceCommandIllegalStateException
      *      unchecked exception if the bean is not in the "initialized" state
      */
     public int getArg_id()
          throws AppInterfaceCommandIllegalStateException { ... }

     /**
      * Returns the command bean's result value for the
      * <code>Customer$id</code> property.
      *
      * @exception AppInterfaceCommandIllegalStateException
      *      unchecked exception if the bean is not in the "executed" state
      */
      public int getResult_Customer$id()
           throws AppInterfaceCommandIllegalStateException { ... }

 
     /**
      * Returns the command bean's result value for the
      * <code>Customer$lastName</code> property.
      *
      * @exception AppInterfaceCommandIllegalStateException
      *      unchecked exception if the bean is not in the "executed" state
      */
     public String getResult_Customer$lastName()
          throws AppInterfaceCommandIllegalStateException { ... }

     /**
      * Returns the command bean's result value for the
      * <code>Customer$firstName</code> property.
      *
      * @exception AppInterfaceCommandIllegalStateException
      *      unchecked exception if the bean is not in the "executed" state
      */
     public String getResult_Customer$firstName()
          throws AppInterfaceCommandIllegalStateException { ... }

     ...
}

 

The client program


Here is an excerpt from a simple Java client that uses the above command bean:

 

import com.seagullsw.appinterface.client.*;
import com.seagullsw.appinterface.client.java.*;
 
public class GetCustomerClient {
 
     public static void main( String[] args ) {
 
          GetCustomerCommand commandBean = new GetCustomerCommand();
 
          commandBean.setArg_id( 12345 ); // Supply an input value.
 
          try {
              // execute() method inherited from superclass, AppInterfaceCommand
              commandBean.execute();
          }
          catch( AppInterfaceCommandInvocationException ex ) {
               System.out.println( "Cannot invoke GetCustomer: " + ex );
          }
          catch( AppInterfaceCommandFailureResponseException ex ) {
               System.out.println(
                    "Failure response for GetCustomer: "
                         + "code = " + ex.getReturnCode()
                         + ", description = " + ex.getDescription() );
               System.out.println( ex );
          }
 
          System.out.println( "Customer: " );
          System.out.println( " lastName: " + commandBean.getResult_Customer$lastName() );
          System.out.println( " firstName: " + commandBean.getResult_Customer$firstName() );
          . . .
     }
}


Basically, you set the argument (input) values, execute the function, and then extract the result (output) values.  Most of the actual work is performed by the AppInterfaceCommand and AppInterfaceConnection classes that are part of the client runtime library supplied with the Application Interface Server.

 

 

Command Bean Class Comment

 

For completeness and convenience, we reproduce here the sort of class comment that is generated for every command bean.  This comment aspires to capture the essential usage rules and patterns that command bean clients are expected to follow.  As such, the class comment is intended to serve as a primary client reference, providing additional feature coverage and clarification that may be absent from the example just considered.

 

/**
 * Application Command Bean for Application Interface Function:
 * com.seagullsw.unittest.appinterface.client.java.GetCustomer
 * -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- --
 *
 * This "application command bean" (or "host function access bean")
 * is autogenerated, e.g. from the "Publish -> Client Command Beans"
 * operation of the Interface Definition Tool, as a subclass of the
 * system-provided abstract superclass AppInterfaceCommand.
 *
 *           *** USAGE RULES AND PATTERNS ***
 *
 * 1. INSTANTIATE:
 * Instantiate a command bean for a function invocation.
 * Two constructors are provided: one configures the bean with a default
 * socket-based connection to an Application Interface Server (AIS) on
 * the "localhost", the other with a socket- or HTTP-based connection
 * to a (remote) server at a specified IP address and port number.
 * Consult the comments for these constructors, which correspond to
 * AppInterfaceCommand() and AppInterfaceCommand(AppInterfaceConnection).
 * Note that while command beans are reusable (items 8. and 9. below),
 * they are not multithreaded.
 *
 * 2. SET ARGUMENTS (INPUT PROPERTIES):
 * Supply function argument values with the bean's setArg_xxx() APIs.
 *
 * 3. EXECUTE:
 * Invoke the host function by calling the bean's no-argument execute()
 * API, inherited from the superclass AppInterfaceCommand.
 * The execute() call can throw checked exceptions extending
 * AppInterfaceCommandException, namely:
 *
 *      AppInterfaceCommandInvocationException,
 *
 * signaling a function invocation or processing error, or
 *
 *      AppInterfaceCommandFailureResponseException,
 *
 * signaling normal function return but with a failure code set
 * in the response. This latter exception may be queried with
 * getReturnCode() and getDescription().
 * 
 * If the bean's connection object has not explicitly been opened
 * with AppInterfaceConnection.open(), then the connection will
 * automatically be opened, the request executed in a separate
 * session, and finally the connection closed. Alternatively, the
 * bean's connection may first be opened explicitly, after which
 * all subsequent invocations of execute() will be processed
 * in the same session until the connection is explicitly closed
 * with AppInterfaceConnection.close().
 *
 * 4. GET RESULTS (OUTPUT PROPERTIES):
 * Retrieve the desired function result values with the bean's
 * getResult_xxx() APIs; the associated getResultSize_xxx() APIs
 * enable result sequences (if any) to be queried for their size,
 * typically when preparing loops to extract sequence component values.
 *
 * 5. GETTING ARGUMENTS:
 * Similarly, the getArg_xxx() and getArgSize_xxx() APIs accommodate
 * retrieval of argument values from the bean, subsequent to their
 * having been set.
 *
 * 6. COMMAND BEAN STATES:
 * A command bean can be in any of three states: "new", "initialized",
 * or "executed" (the latter two not mutually exclusive), for which
 * it may be queried by means of the APIs isNew(), isInitialized(),
 * and isExecuted(). The bean acquires the "new" state upon construction.
 * It moves to the "initialized" state when all required function
 * arguments have been set (currently, required arguments are not
 * specified or enforced; it is the client's responsibility to ensure
 * that all expected inputs to the function are supplied). Finally,
 * the bean enters the "executed" state provided the execute() call
 * returns a response, even if the response has a failure code
 * (though the checked AppInterfaceCommandFailureResponseException
 * is thrown in that event). Note: even once the bean is "executed",
 * it remains "initialized" so long as all its required arguments
 * have values.
 *
 * 7. COMMAND BEAN EXCEPTIONS:
 * In addition to the checked exceptions already mentioned above,
 * the command bean can throw unchecked exceptions extending
 * AppInterfaceCommandRuntimeException, most notably an
 * AppInterfaceCommandIllegalStateException when an operation
 * is attempted that is inappropriate for the bean's present state.
 *
 * 8. COMMAND BEAN REUSE:
 * A command bean may be reused for subsequent invocations of the
 * same function, after zero or more of its arguments have been set
 * to new values. It is not necessary first to reset or reinitialize
 * the bean, though this may be done as described in the next item.
 *
 * 9. INIT() AND RESET():
 * Two methods are available for clearing a command bean's
 * argument/result values and explicitly resetting its state.
 *
 * The init() method restores the bean to its originally constructed
 * state, in particular clearing the function arguments by initializing
 * a new request object for the bean. After init(), the bean will answer
 * true to isNew() and false to isInitialized() if any required function
 * arguments need to be set; once all required arguments have been set,
 * it will answer false to isNew() and true to isInitialized().
 *
 * The reset() method (inherited from superclass, AppInterfaceCommand)
 * sets the bean's "executed" state to false and nulls out any previous
 * response. As a consequence, attempts to query the bean for its
 * result values will throw an exception until the bean is executed
 * again. The argument values remain unaffected and may be retrieved,
 * if desired, with getArg_xxx() calls as usual.
 */
